Name: OXYTHIOQUINOX
Description: Quinomethionate is a dithioloquinoxaline that results from the formal condensation of 6-methylquinoxaline-2,3-dithiol with phosgene. It has been used as a fungicide and acaricide for the control of mites and powdery mildew on citrus, vegetables, and walnuts, but is not approved for use in the EU. It has a role as an agrochemical. It is a quinoxaline acaricide, a quinoxaline antifungal agent and a dithioloquinoxaline.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Jeppson LR, Gunther FA; Res Rev 33: 101-36 (1970)
plant_concentrations.Value: Chemical residue analyses indicated that initial deposits of oxythioquinox were about 4-14 ppm with a half-life of 34 to 37 days for both lemons and oranges(1). Residues of oxythioquinox are readily washed off fruit by rains or washing; oxythioquinox residues largely remain on the fruit surface rather than penetrate into the wax or the rind(1).

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Tomlin CDS, ed; The e-Pesticide Manual. Oxythioquinox. 13th ed. PC CD-ROM, Version 3.0, 2003-04. Surrey, UK: British Crop Protection Council, (2003) (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994) (4) USDA; ARS Pesticide Properties Database. Data sheet for Quinomethionate. Last updated May 1995. US Dept Agric, Agric Res Serv. Available from, as of May 14, 2005: https://www.ars.usda.gov/Services/docs.htm?docid=14199
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 160 was calculated for oxythioquinox(SRC), using a log Kow of 3.78(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high(SRC), provided the compound is not altered physically or chemically once released into the environment. Oxythioquinox is susceptible to both hydrolysis(1) and photolysis in water(4).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) USDA; ARS Pesticide Properties Database. Data sheet for Quinomethionate. Last updated May 1995. US Dept Agric, Agric Res Serv. Available from, as of May 14, 2005: https://www.ars.usda.gov/Services/docs.htm?docid=14199
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Field dissipation half-lives of 2.0-3.6 days have been reported for oxythioquinox in two sandy loam soils(1).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) USDA; ARS Pesticide Properties Database. Data sheet for Quinomethionate. Last updated May 1995. US Dept Agric, Agric Res Serv. Available from, as of May 14, 2005: https://www.ars.usda.gov/Services/docs.htm?docid=14199
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: A half-life of 3.7 days was reported for oxythioquinox in sandy loam soil under anaerobic conditions(1). The nitrogen-containing ring structure of oxythioquinox is apparently not cleaved by anaerobic ecosystems(2).

logP.References: Tomlin CDS, ed; The e-Pesticide Manual. Oxythioquinox. 13th ed. PC CD-ROM, Version 3.0, 2003-04. Surrey, UK: British Crop Protection Council, (2003)

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Wauchope RD et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 123: 1-36 (1991) (2) USDA; ARS Pesticide Properties Database. Data sheet for Quinomethionate. Last updated May 1995. US Dept Agric, Agric Res Serv. Available from, as of May 14, 2005: https://www.ars.usda.gov/Services/docs.htm?docid=14199 (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983) (4) Helling CS, et al; Phytopathology 64: 1091-100 (1974)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Koc values ranging from 2,300 to 28,235 have been reported for oxythioquinox on various soil types(1,2). According to a classification scheme(3), this estimated Koc value suggests that oxythioquinox is expected to have slight to no mobility in soil. The mobility of oxythioquinox was tested in a soil thin-layer chromatographic system using Hagerstown silty clay loam (surface soil with 2.5% organic material, 39.5% clay, soil water content is 34.1%, pH is 6.8)(4). Oxythioquinox was immobile by both autoradiographic and bioassay visualization using the TLC system indicating strong absorption to the soil medium(4).
